[2024-12-21T14:00:37] Face de Pin Suc√©: Don't get me wrong, I helped you in the past, look at the conversation, but people need to understand one thing : Buying a controller doesn't mean the seller will take free time to set up My customers paies me to install and make a configuration on their scooters, so those are guaranteed. When you buy a flipsky or anything else, you don't ask Flipsky to make your setup. Regarding the canbus broken, from my memories, you put B+ in wrong place in the controller. Repairing it doesn't mean it will work indefinitely, because all the components on the line that shouldn't be supplied with this voltage can be damaged. And changing a component by resoldering it, can work for a time, and break again. I apologize for not responding on your asking of help, but you need to understand, I have very much messages, and sometimes, I see them, then forget or no time to answer, and I don't put those asks in my to-do list.
[2024-12-21T14:02:01] Face de Pin Suc√©: And this connector doesn't break by itself, it is a Molex Microclasp, very good quality connectors, and never broke one, so might be something wrong, like the cable is in tension or during disassembly

[2024-12-22T02:11:27] Matthew: I have a single 65h 22x3 winding lonnyo motor and the motor is amazing but if you intend on cruising faster than 35mph it will get hot on you. 22x3 i found out is best for dual motor or if you cruise slower in general and just like to have spirited top speed runs and random acceleration single is fine. If you want to cruise 45mph you most definitely will need to have dual motor in my recent experience. If there's ways I'm doing things wrong I would really like to know because I'm quite a newb to be honest.
[2024-12-22T02:17:48] Matthew: I posted a while back that I get what I'd Iike to describe as a fluttering once I reach a certain speed. I'm using a single ubox 85150 on 18s 90 amp battery 150 amp phase with 70amps fw. Even when fw is turned off I still have the issue. I have a 65h 22x3 lonnyo motor and I had the same issue using a vsett 10+ motor. Going to post a video which the speed run starts almost 10 seconds into the video and approaching speed of ~40mph is when I start having the issue. When I back off the throttle and get back into it sometimes the fluttering completely stops or if not I seem to find a point to hover with the throttle that is just below the "issue" and then towards top speed i can go full throttle without feeling the fluttering. I'm also going to post a bunch of pics of my settings.

[2024-12-29T00:46:32] Matthew: I have the 85150 units. I don't think you can go wrong with them. Not only do they handle a crazy amount of power for what they are dude I messaged recently is running 230amps phase out of a single 85150. I'm not like some of you that have 20kw at hand on the regular but 115amp battery and 150 amp per motor phase, that was very powerful and "jerky" with a thumb throttle, I understand a spin throttle takes care of the jerky inputs. I started with 60 amps phase per motor once installed and configured and kept going up. At the point I was at 120amps phase per motor i said fuck it and went to 160amp phase per motor and the front wheel came up off the ground. I was running 2 vsett 10+ motors at the time.

[2024-12-30T14:15:49] Jerome (St0fzuiger üõ¥ ): Any lisp script wizzards here? Trying to make a lisp script that multiply a current when a current has been set. (This is due the VESC bridge for the GT's we have that sends 1 current to all controllers but when using dual motor setup and heavier controller / motor we want to have higher current on that one. Unfortunate no memory in Bridge STM available to handle that so idea is to use a lisp script. This should do the trick but seems not to work :( (defun main () "Main function to read, modify, and set current with controlled looping when changed." ;; Define a multiplier value (let ((multiplier 1.5)) ; Replace with your desired multiplier (loop ;; Read current value (let* ((current (get-current)) (new-current (* current multiplier))) ; Multiply current value ;; Prevent setting the same value to avoid unnecessary loops (if (not (= current new-current)) (progn ;; Log the values for debugging (print (str-format "Current value: ~a" current)) (print (str-format "New current value: ~a" new-current)) ;; Set the new current value (set-current new-current)) ;; Exit the loop if values are the same (progn (print "No update needed; current value unchanged.") (return)))))))

[2025-01-06T11:36:09] Yamal: New VESC
[2025-01-06T11:36:50] Yamal: I didn't know it existed, only Thor 300
[2025-01-06T11:37:21] Yamal: 18fet
[2025-01-06T11:38:40] Yamal: Tolt üò± December 2023: A big problem in the community - folks want to build Higher Voltage builds, but there are no suitable ESCs available.. A few months later, an e-scooter/ e-bike controller emerges that people start using for HV builds. Great controller! However, it's big, bulky, doesnt fit most connectors/ enclosures. No dedicated footpad connector/ hall sensor ports dont match, no direct LED support, etc... Early 2024: I get on a call with our internal design team. Here's how the call goes: Me- We want a a controller capable of 32S/ 135V, and upto 400 amps abs. max. A DEDICATED Funwheel/ VESC-wheel controller. Designer - Sure that can be done. Me- ...and we want it in the same space and same bolt pattern and layout as the Thor300. Designer-..that...might be impossible... Well, that's how it began, a lot of impossible things later, the Thor400-32S was born. Here are some mind blowing specs: True 32S controller (with all HV components rated to 150V! perhaps the only one in the industry...perhaps). Extremely expensive and reliable OnSemi Dual cool Automotive Tech FETs. We have 18 of these FETs in this extremely small package. Providing unrivaled power with TOLT/ Dual cool technology. Forget overheating controllers. 400A abs. max current (depending on cooling/ Fungineers box is recommended). Same bolting pattern and size as the Thor300. Fits in the Fungineers box and still has space for 2S2P 21700 (400A in this package is unheard of!). Same onboard LED support as the Thor300 (just plug in the status, front, and rear led). Choice to run 5V or 12V LEDs (can be switched with a jumper!) ESP32 breakout pins to run additional functions. 12V/ 5V additional pads to run 5A (max with cooling) LEDs or other functions! Sin/Cos encoder Support. Additional temperature probe support (to monitor temperature of your split pack). ebike throttle support (Can be switched with a jumper). Roll to start: Currently in beta. Improved robustness and design - stronger, and more rigid than ever. Momentary button: Same button and pins as the Thor300, but improved hardware and logic. VESC Express onboard Bluetooth/ Wifi module; preconfigured. XT90 connector. In short, the Thor400 is NOT for Onewheels/ Funwheels. This is an ebike/ EUC worthy Controller that will turn your Funwheel into an absolute beast; and you can be sure your Funwheel is 100% future proof with the Thor400 due to the bleeding edge features.

[2025-01-09T00:14:56] cihan: If you dig deep down on it, it's problem of free market economy. Free market economy has some axioms. One of them is "all consumers can reach enough knowledge about all goods being sold to compare them and also can reach all price tags." This is false, consumers cannot know enough to evaluate all goods being sold and also cannot reach all price tags for same goods. So this is one big disadvantage of free market economy. That's something unavoidable.

[2025-01-27T03:36:20] Matthew: Different techniques for mig and Different alloys and processes. There's inner shield flux core wire that's basically the stick welding in the mig world. Dual shield flux core which can be an absolute dream to run at times. Certain alloys really suck to weld with mig. Then there's basic solid "hard wire" the hard wire is ran with different gas mixtures and different positions.

[2025-01-30T14:15:08] francois schempers: Buy/Sell/Trade (BST) Channel Guidelines 1) - Purpose - A dedicated space for members to buy, sell, or trade items and services. Keep all listings/transactions within this channel to avoid spamming the main community chat. 2) - Posting Format Item/Service: Give a clear name and brief description. Price or Trade Terms: State your price (or that you‚Äôre open to offers, trades, etc.). Location: If relevant (especially for physical goods or in-person meetups). Payment & Shipping: Preferred payment methods (PayPal, etc.) and whether you ship or do local pickup. References: (Optional) Link to your profile in the Feedback & Reputation channel if you have reviews, or mention if you‚Äôre new. 3) - Honesty & Transparency Provide accurate descriptions, photos, and mention any defects or missing parts. If requested, be willing to show proof of ownership or authenticity. 4) - Respectful Interaction Keep negotiations civil‚Äîno name-calling or harassment. If you have concerns about a seller or item, politely ask for clarifications or move to private messages. 5) - Disclaimer Admins are not responsible for the outcome of any deal. All transactions are private agreements between buyer and seller. Do your own due diligence (ask for photos, references, proof of purchase, etc.). 6) - Disputes & Moderation If a transaction goes sour, attempt to resolve privately first. Serious complaints can be posted (factually) in the Feedback & Reputation channel, but keep it civil. Admins may remove posts or participants that break rules or cause significant disruption.
[2025-01-30T14:19:20] francois schempers: Feedback & Reputation Channel Guidelines 1) - Purpose A central location where members can leave positive, neutral, or negative feedback on transactions completed via our BST channel (or elsewhere in the community). Helps the community make informed decisions when dealing with specific buyers or sellers. 2) - Posting Format Transaction Date: Approximate timeline or date of the transaction. Party Involved: Tag the buyer/seller. Item/Service: Brief mention of what was sold or bought. Feedback: Positive, neutral, or negative A short factual description (e.g., ‚ÄúGreat communication, fast shipping‚Äù or ‚ÄúDelayed response, item not as described‚Äù). 3) - Keep It Factual & Polite Stick to what happened: Was payment prompt? Did the item match the description? Any communication issues? No personal attacks or inflammatory language‚Äîfocus on the transaction details. 4) - Admin Oversight Posts with insults, threats, or harassment will be removed. Repeated or severe violations can result in a warning, mute, or ban depending on severity. 5) - Reference Links Feel free to link to relevant BST posts or share screenshots of your conversation (with sensitive info redacted), if needed, to provide context. 6) - Professional Tone Constructive, clear feedback benefits everyone. Encourage others to do the same to maintain a transparent buying/selling environment.
[2025-01-30T14:21:16] francois schempers: Trusted Seller Channel Guidelines 1) - Purpose & Structure A closed/archived channel featuring a curated list of verified or ‚Äútrusted‚Äù sellers. Only these trusted sellers can post here; the channel is otherwise read-only. 2) - Who Qualifies Community Sellers with consistent positive feedback and a reliable track record. Professional Physical Shops that provide evidence of their business registration or proven credibility (they may include a link to their shop website). 3) - Trusted Seller Posts Each trusted seller is allowed one pinned post (or a single ongoing thread in the channel). They must keep it updated with: Available Items/Services Prices/Rates Links to Feedback in the Feedback & Reputation channel Shop Link (if a professional seller) Contact Info (preferably a business or public account for shops) 4) - Maintenance & Removal Admins reserve the right to remove a seller from the channel if complaints or unresolved disputes arise. Sellers must keep their info current‚Äîstale or irrelevant posts can be unpinned or archived. 5) - Disclaimer Trusted does not mean flawless‚Äîalways verify details before completing a transaction. Admins are not liable for deals gone wrong, even with trusted sellers. 6) - Evolving Criteria As the community grows, standards for becoming/removing a trusted seller may change. Check pinned admin announcements for updates.

[2025-01-31T08:41:32] Jerome (St0fzuiger üõ¥ ): As you might have heard the VESC Bridge V2 is coming soon. Since there are many changes and the V1 had a massive limit in available memory we have decided to create the V2 version from scratch. This means no upgrade path available for the V1's but involves new hardware. First of all what is the VESC bridge ..... VESC bridge was originally made for the Segway GT1 & GT2 to be able to use VESC controllers but still keep most of the stock functions working. So at the end your dash, RGB, lights and even the original app kept working but you could use much more powerful speed controllers. Also you where able to convert a GT1 single motor to dual motor with it and it has some extra feature that are controlled by it's own VESC Bridge App (PowerNine). Here you where able to set power settings for each motor and define the speed for each driving mode. It could let a dual motor GT1 boot into 2WD mode and provided as hidden function a way to switch to 1 or 2 motors. Also it has a speed regulated mode where the scooter boots into speed limit mode and via hidden function this could be activated and would activate always when you where in a certain mode. The V1 bridge can do much more but would be a long list :). Anyway V2 is on it's way and like V1 it provides a plug & play solution to have VESC in your scooter but now it's not limited anymore to just the Segway GT1 & GT2 but also Ninebot G30 & G2 is now supported (Different bridge hardware for each although). With plug and play we mean take out original esc add VESC(s) and plug the original cables into the Bridge and hook up the bridge to the main VESC and done. (Note except Hall cable & Motor cable) What features will V2 have (some might be delayed or skipped) - Total redesigned hardware with own power stage (VESC 5V is a mess) - OTA firmware upgrades - Stock battery support & Unlock BMS for G30 (GT series is under investigation) - Real anti theft mode that locks the motors fully (using Handbrake function of VESC) - Power shifting (Torque curve) during first xx Km of speed where amps on front motor are reduced and given to rear motor (User adjustable) - DAC support for users that want to use the ADC function of VESC. No extra wiring required. - Cruise control support - Battery current Max regen per motor adjustable (v1 used same as regular motor current) - Speed regulated speeds & power adjustable (V1 was fixed) - RGB Function and Guard mode in Powernine app (Make it less dependent of Ninebot app) The might comes features: (no hard promise!) - Additional BMS support like JBD (Done), JK (WIP), Ant (WIP), Daly (WIP) - 2 inputs and 2 outputs to be able to add turn lights (G30, G2) - Per motor Battery & Phase settings (V1 could not set Battery amp per motor) When there are additions we will mention them in follow up posts. ETA for VESC Bridge V2 is roughly Mid April and the price is not fully clear yet but we expect not (much) more then the V1 bridge (+- 50 Euro + Shipping).
[2025-01-31T08:42:04] francois schempers: As you might have heard the VESC Bridge V2 is coming soon. Since there are many changes and the V1 had a massive limit in available memory we have decided to create the V2 version from scratch. This means no upgrade path available for the V1's but involves new hardware. First of all what is the VESC bridge ..... VESC bridge was originally made for the Segway GT1 & GT2 to be able to use VESC controllers but still keep most of the stock functions working. So at the end your dash, RGB, lights and even the original app kept working but you could use much more powerful speed controllers. Also you where able to convert a GT1 single motor to dual motor with it and it has some extra feature that are controlled by it's own VESC Bridge App (PowerNine). Here you where able to set power settings for each motor and define the speed for each driving mode. It could let a dual motor GT1 boot into 2WD mode and provided as hidden function a way to switch to 1 or 2 motors. Also it has a speed regulated mode where the scooter boots into speed limit mode and via hidden function this could be activated and would activate always when you where in a certain mode. The V1 bridge can do much more but would be a long list :). Anyway V2 is on it's way and like V1 it provides a plug & play solution to have VESC in your scooter but now it's not limited anymore to just the Segway GT1 & GT2 but also Ninebot G30 & G2 is now supported (Different bridge hardware for each although). With plug and play we mean take out original esc add VESC(s) and plug the original cables into the Bridge and hook up the bridge to the main VESC and done. (Note except Hall cable & Motor cable) What features will V2 have (some might be delayed or skipped) - Total redesigned hardware with own power stage (VESC 5V is a mess) - OTA firmware upgrades - Stock battery support & Unlock BMS for G30 (GT series is under investigation) - Real anti theft mode that locks the motors fully (using Handbrake function of VESC) - Power shifting (Torque curve) during first xx Km of speed where amps on front motor are reduced and given to rear motor (User adjustable) - DAC support for users that want to use the ADC function of VESC. No extra wiring required. - Cruise control support - Battery current Max regen per motor adjustable (v1 used same as regular motor current) - Speed regulated speeds & power adjustable (V1 was fixed) - RGB Function and Guard mode in Powernine app (Make it less dependent of Ninebot app) The might comes features: (no hard promise!) - Additional BMS support like JBD (Done), JK (WIP), Ant (WIP), Daly (WIP) - 2 inputs and 2 outputs to be able to add turn lights (G30, G2) - Per motor Battery & Phase settings (V1 could not set Battery amp per motor) When there are additions we will mention them in follow up posts. ETA for VESC Bridge V2 is roughly Mid April and the price is not fully clear yet but we expect not (much) more then the V1 bridge (+- 50 Euro + Shipping).

[2025-02-02T01:32:35] Matthew: I have 22x3 and wish I would have gone 60h 17x4 instead of 65h 22x3. Once moving about 15mph and up single motor pushes well. But from 0 speed start the torque is definitely lackluster and should be used as dual motor though dual motor will be insane depending on the power you're throw at the motors. From what I've gathered 30mph cruise speed for 65h single motor runs great and acceleration is strong.. start going over 30mph the single motor for me starts getting hot. Input from someone the motor i should have bought is 60h 17x4 which was told 40mph doesn't get hot and with some fw ~50mph top speed capable.

[2025-02-02T20:11:46] 'lekrsu': Phase amps is your motor amps, battery amps is self explanatory. Your battery amps * battery voltage = motor amps * motor voltage. Full speed, full motor voltage, means battery voltage = motor voltage, and phase current equals battery current.

[2025-02-15T12:41:56] Jan: Another question about field weakening. Why though? The way i see it, people have too powerful setups for their low kv motors, needing then to compensate the magnetic field with "wasted counter" current just to go faster. Why not just a higher kv motor to begin with when you have the powerful setup. Isnt the loss of power to field weakening just about the extras power you could pump into a higher kv motor to get the same acceleration?

When I was doing my motor detection, my front motor was running normally, but the rear one was completely going out of control. My motor was also vibrating when stationary, moving left and right. When I released my throttle, it would suddenly accelerate at full speed for about half a second. My ADC was going crazy, jumping from 20% to 100%. This happened since I switched to a 300X throttle instead of the Spin Y2.
[2025-02-15T19:49:08] ‚ú®üá™üá∏ÿπŸÖÿ±: All of this started when I switched to the 300X because the Spin Y2 failed on me.
[2025-02-15T19:50:00] ‚ú®üá™üá∏ÿπŸÖÿ±: I was able to partially solve the problem by separating the Bluetooth module, the CAN bus, and the throttle because I had them tied together with a plastic zip tie. I spaced them out properly, kept them away from the motor phases as well, and switched to BLDC mode to reduce the jerks caused by the throttle.

[2025-02-22T19:54:27] francois schempers: Short Answer The q-axis current factor (often shown in VESC as foc_fw_q_current_factor) is a small fraction of your field-weakening current that gets applied against the motor‚Äôs usual torque direction. In simpler terms, it‚Äôs a tiny built-in ‚Äúnegative torque‚Äù or braking effect whenever field weakening is active, helping the controller avoid overshoot or runaway speeds near top RPM. A typical default (like 2%) means you add about 2% of the FW current as a controlled braking force on the q-axis. Deeper Explanation Context: Field Weakening (FW) Field Weakening injects negative d-axis current so you can spin the motor faster than its natural ‚Äúbase speed.‚Äù For example, you might see a 10‚Äì20% higher top speed. However, once you‚Äôre above that base speed (i.e., in FW territory), the motor can become less stable if there‚Äôs zero demand on the torque axis (q-axis). The controller might lose some control or let the motor ‚Äúspin freely‚Äù if you abruptly close the throttle. What the Q-Axis Factor Does Q-axis is your main torque-producing axis. The parameter foc_fw_q_current_factor says, ‚ÄúTake a small portion of the field-weakening current and apply it negatively on the q-axis.‚Äù Effect: This small negative torque counters freewheeling or overshoot at high speed. In essence, it provides a light, automatic braking when you‚Äôre in high-duty or field-weakening conditions and not demanding forward power. Why It‚Äôs Helpful Safety Net: If you have no q-axis braking at all (i.e. factor = 0), you can get situations where the motor coasts above the desired speed or the firmware is slow to respond if you suddenly let go of throttle. Smoother Transitions: With a small factor (like 2%), you get a gentle ‚Äúdrag‚Äù that keeps the controller‚Äôs observer stable, preventing big ‚Äúwind-up‚Äù or random jerkiness in the transition from acceleration to coasting. Typical Values 2% is often used as a default so you don‚Äôt even notice the braking under normal riding; it‚Äôs just enough to help with control and keep everything stable during field weakening. Higher Values (5‚Äì10%) result in a stronger negative torque at top speeds, which might feel like early ‚Äúengine brake.‚Äù If you find you‚Äôre losing too much top-end or it‚Äôs too draggy, you‚Äôd lower this factor. When to Adjust If you‚Äôre happy with how your scooter coasts at high speed and see no weird surging, you can leave it. If you experience overshoot (the motor spinning uncomfortably fast the moment you ease off throttle) or any ‚Äúflutter‚Äù after letting go of throttle near top speed, increasing this factor a bit might help. If you feel you have too much engine braking and it‚Äôs hurting top-end performance, reducing this below 2% (or going to 0%) will remove that slight auto-brake effect‚Äîbut be careful not to let the FW ‚Äúrun away.‚Äù In Summary Your ‚Äú2%‚Äù q-axis current factor is basically a gentle negative torque added on top of field weakening. It‚Äôs there to keep the motor stable and avoid free-spinning or overshooting. Most riders find the small default value a good balance between retaining smooth coasting and preventing unwanted drifting or surging at high speeds. If your scooter feels fine, 2% is usually right where you want it.

[2025-02-22T21:00:48] francois schempers: Overmodulation is a technique in Field-Oriented Control (FOC) where the ESC deliberately drives the motor beyond the standard 100% modulation limit. In typical FOC: You apply three-phase sinewaves whose peak amplitude never reaches the full DC-bus voltage. If you think of ‚Äú100% duty cycle‚Äù as the maximum continuous sine amplitude you can swing, then going beyond it would distort that sine wave into a trapezoid (or hexagon shape in space-vector modulation). By overmodulating (e.g., setting foc_overmod_factor to 1.05 or 1.15), the controller: 1. Pushes the motor voltage higher at peak demand, effectively approaching or briefly exceeding the normal ‚Äúsinewave boundary.‚Äù 2. Gains a slight speed or torque benefit near the motor‚Äôs upper RPM range, because it can supply a bit more voltage to overcome back-EMF. 3. However, introduces distortion in the waveforms. Instead of a pure sine, you end up with partial ‚Äú6-step‚Äù behavior at the top end. Why Use It? Extra Top Speed: Overmodulation can give you 5‚Äì15% more RPM without requiring full Field Weakening. Simpler Implementation: You don‚Äôt have to inject much (or any) negative d-current. Overmod is mostly a software tweak in the PWM space-vector routine. Downsides Wave Distortion ‚Üí extra motor noise or potential torque ripple. You might feel slightly rougher operation at high throttle. More Switch Stresses: You‚Äôre running very close to bus voltage, so big transients (like letting off throttle quickly) can spike the ESC. Limited Gain: It‚Äôs just a small margin (say 1.05 to 1.15). If you want significantly higher speed, you still need Field Weakening or higher battery voltage. Practical Setting in VESC The parameter foc_overmod_factor typically defaults to 1.0 (disabled). If you set it to 1.1 or 1.15, it means at max throttle, the controller can stretch beyond 100% sine amplitude up to 110‚Äì115%. That yields a small ‚Äúoverdrive‚Äù zone. In sum, overmodulation is a way to squeeze extra RPM or power from the same voltage, but at the expense of more waveform distortion and potential extra stress on the system. It‚Äôs often a smaller, simpler ‚Äúboost‚Äù compared to full-blown Field Weakening.

[2025-02-22T21:51:12] Jerome (St0fzuiger üõ¥ ): Ok here is one .... When using MTPA (yeah i know ......) it gives massive torque but trips overcurrent (regardless of IQ Measured or IQ Target) to keep that under control i use input current map limit (95%). But what would be better solution to reach similar torque but stay within the limits of the ESC? We are just trail & error busy with the GT rebuilds and just want to squeeze out the max but still have torque to be able to get quick enough to top speed. (If required can send set of motor / app cfg's)
[2025-02-22T21:57:02] francois schempers: Q: *‚ÄúWhen using MTPA (IQ Target or IQ Measured) on our scooter, we get incredible torque but keep tripping overcurrent. We tried limiting input current to ~95% as a workaround, but is there a better way to achieve strong torque without blowing the ESC?‚Äù* Below is a deeper look at *why* MTPA can overshoot current and *what* alternative tweaks or techniques you can do to keep peak torque high but avoid ESC faults. --- ## 1. Why MTPA Causes Overcurrent 1. Negative D-axis Injection - By design, MTPA injects negative d-axis current to exploit the motor‚Äôs Ld‚ÄìLq difference (saliency). This can produce a *very* high torque spike when the motor is in the right speed/load zone. 2. Instantaneous Current Surges - If your motor‚Äôs inductance is not large enough, or if your ESC sees a sudden jump in Q-axis demand plus the negative D-axis from MTPA, the *actual phase current* can spike well beyond your usual limit. - Even though the *average* might be under your setting, the *peak* can briefly exceed l_abs_current_max or cause ‚Äúabs_over_current‚Äù faults. 3. Battery vs. Motor Current - At partial duty, the ESC is ‚Äústepping down‚Äù voltage, so the motor can pull large phase amps. In MTPA, you‚Äôre pushing negative d-current in addition to normal q-current. If that‚Äôs not carefully clamped, the phase amps can blow past safe levels. --- ## 2. Approaches to Control MTPA Overshoot ### 2.1 Limit the Negative d-axis Injection (MTPA Strength) If your firmware supports it, you can: - Use a smaller Ld‚ÄìLq difference: Some advanced builds artificially lower the ‚Äúfoc_motor_ld_lq_diff‚Äù parameter (e.g. from 0.000004 to 0.000003) so the controller calculates less negative d-current. - Cap the negative d-current: Certain VESC forks or more recent versions let you define a maximum negative d-axis (like a ‚Äúd-axis clamp‚Äù). That‚Äôs a direct way to ‚Äúsoften‚Äù MTPA‚Äôs injection so it‚Äôs not so aggressive. > Effect: You keep *some* benefit from MTPA, but you won‚Äôt see huge over-shoot. The motor won‚Äôt produce the absolute peak torque, but you‚Äôre less likely to pass overcurrent thresholds. --- ### 2.2 Shorten the MTPA Range (Duty or Speed) If your motor only benefits from MTPA in a certain RPM window (e.g., mid-speed), you can: - Use standard torque at low RPM (where overcurrent is biggest risk). - Enable MTPA above a certain duty cycle or speed threshold. > This can be done by hacking observer code or using scripting to turn on MTPA partially. It‚Äôs more advanced, but it effectively reduces the times you combine large q-current + big negative d-current. --- ### 2.3 Use a Smaller ‚ÄúInput Current Map Start‚Äù You mentioned you‚Äôre at 95% (0.95). You can try: - Go lower, e.g. 80‚Äì90%. Then your Q-axis is forced to scale back earlier, preventing the huge torque spikes that occur if MTPA is piling on negative d-current at the same time. - Pros: You still have MTPA for quick torque below that fraction of max input current, but it ramps down so you don‚Äôt cross ESC‚Äôs safety margin. - Cons: You might lose some top-end grunt if you rely on that last 10‚Äì20% of input amps for big speed runs. --- ### 2.4 More Conservative Current Limits (Phase or Battery) 1. Phase Current: If you suspect MTPA pushes you from, say, 150‚Äì160 A to 200‚Äì220 A ‚Äúspikes,‚Äù reduce ‚ÄúMotor Current Max‚Äù to ~120‚Äì130 A. The negative d-current still yields strong torque, but the absolute peak is now clamped. 2. Battery Current: If your BMS or battery can‚Äôt handle sudden surges, you can‚Äôt rely on l_in_current_max alone. Overcurrent is often *phase* limited, so it‚Äôs the ‚Äúl_current_max‚Äù (motor amps) that helps more. > Tip: In many high-power setups, simply lowering phase amps by 10‚Äì20% still gives 90% of the seat-of-pants torque, but drastically lowers the chance of blowouts. --- ### 2.5 Softer Throttle or Torque Ramp
[2025-02-22T21:57:02] francois schempers: - Throttle Curve: Setting a non-linear throttle ramp so that the last 20% of throttle is ‚Äúexpanded.‚Äù This means the motor doesn‚Äôt jump from 60% to 100% q-current instantly, giving the controller time to catch the big surge. - Current Ramp Step (cc_ramp_step_max or ‚Äúthrottle ramp‚Äù): If you let the current build up slightly slower, MTPA won't spike as violently in the first milliseconds of throttle. > Benefit: You can preserve high max amps but avoid a short spike that triggers ABS Overcurrent. Just a small smoothing factor can help. --- ## 3. Which Is ‚ÄúBest‚Äù? 1. If you want maximum mid-range torque: *Limiting negative D-axis injection* is probably the more direct approach. It stays within your ESC capabilities, but still harnesses MTPA. 2. If you‚Äôre already comfortable with partial torque: *Reducing motor current max* is simplest. 3. If your main problem is short surges: *Slowing throttle ramp or setting a more advanced ramp curve* can keep you from crossing that overcurrent threshold in the first place. 4. Combining: Some do both partial negative-d clamp and a smaller input current map start (maybe 80‚Äì85%) to ensure you never jump into meltdown territory. --- ## 4. Additional Debug Steps 1. Log Actual Phase Current - If your firmware or VESC variant can, record real-time stats. See exactly how high the phase amps go during your MTPA ‚Äúblow past limit‚Äù event. That helps you pick a new clamp more precisely. 2. Try Slightly Lower ‚Äúfoc_motor_ld_lq_diff‚Äù - If detection gave you, e.g., 3.7e-6, experiment with 2.9‚Äì3.0e-6. That artificially reduces the MTPA injection. If the motor is truly IPM, you still get a torque boost, just not as extreme. 3. Recheck Overmodulation / Field Weakening - If you are also using a big ‚Äúovermod factor‚Äù or ‚Äúfield weakening,‚Äù the combined effect with MTPA can cause bigger overshoots. Maybe reduce FW or keep it only for high RPM so you don‚Äôt stack them at mid speeds. --- ## 5. Conclusion - Input Current Map Limit is a decent workaround but can sometimes strangle the last bit of acceleration you want. A more elegant solution is capping the negative D-axis used by MTPA or slightly lowering phase amps** so your ESC never sees those lethal current spikes. - In short, if you aim for ‚Äúsqueeze-out‚Äù performance but keep reliability: 1. Reduce MTPA aggression (Ld‚ÄìLq or negative-D clamp) 2. Modulate ramp (throttle / torque ramp) 3. Tune your input current map more narrowly (80‚Äì90% instead of 95%), or 4. Lower motor max amps by ~10‚Äì15% That way you still get excellent torque and decent top speed but avoid immediate overcurrent triggers. A lot of *trial & error* is normal: watch your real-time logs, see what peak phase amps appear, and fine-tune from there.

[2025-02-22T22:06:04] Jerome (St0fzuiger üõ¥ ): Damn ..... This is amazing food for reading and mostly spot on .... (now searching for that damn "Cap the negative d-current" using 6.06 but doesnt look it has it (or me stupid)
[2025-02-22T22:13:41] francois schempers: Q: *‚ÄúIn firmware 6.06, I can‚Äôt find the ‚ÄòCap negative d-current‚Äô parameter you mentioned‚Äîam I missing something? Or is it simply not there?‚Äù* Below is some background on that feature and what you *can* do in the standard firmware: --- ## 1. Official Firmware Doesn‚Äôt Directly Expose a ‚ÄúNegative D Clamp‚Äù - As of 6.0x (including 6.06), the mainline VESC code hasn‚Äôt offered a user-facing parameter called ‚Äúd-axis clamp‚Äù or ‚Äúmax negative Id.‚Äù Instead, MTPA is toggled by: - Setting foc_mtpa_mode = IQ_TARGET or IQ_MEASURED, - Using foc_motor_ld_lq_diff to define saliency, - Possibly adjusting foc_motor_flux_linkage, etc. The firmware then calculates negative d-current automatically, based on real-time torque demands. There‚Äôs *no direct slider* to say ‚Äúdon‚Äôt exceed -20A on d-axis,‚Äù for example‚Äîunless you modify the code or use a specialized branch. --- ## 2. Workaround Approaches ### 2.1 ‚ÄúFake‚Äù Lower Motor Saliency (foc_motor_ld_lq_diff) - The simplest, though indirect, method is to slightly reduce foc_motor_ld_lq_diff from your measured value. - Result: The firmware believes the motor‚Äôs Ld‚ÄìLq difference is smaller, so it calculates less negative d-axis current. - Practical Example: - If detection gave you 3.7e-6, try 2.8‚Äì3.0e-6. - You‚Äôll get a milder MTPA effect, thus fewer big spikes. Caution: Reducing it too much may practically disable MTPA. If you want some MTPA, you have to find a sweet spot by trial & error. --- ### 2.2 Lower the Overall Phase Current - If your biggest problem is short spikes, one broad approach is to set l_current_max to a modest number. Because negative d-current *adds* to the Q-axis current for total phase amplitude. - Even dropping motor amps by ~10% can push the peaks below the ESC‚Äôs overcurrent threshold. - Not as ‚Äúsurgical‚Äù as a d-axis clamp, but easy to do in the VESC Tool. --- ### 2.3 Throttle/Torque Ramp Adjustments - In the ‚ÄúCurrent‚Äù or ‚ÄúDuty‚Äù control page, look for cc_ramp_step_max or ‚Äúacceleration‚Äù settings. - By limiting how fast the ESC can demand full torque, you give MTPA less chance to cause a sudden blow-up. - End result: You still see near the same torque, but it might take a fraction of a second longer to ramp up‚Äîlowering the instantaneous current spike. --- ### 2.4 Experimental Code Forks - Some ‚Äúprivate‚Äù or alternative VESC forks (for instance, certain e-bike or e-scooter dev branches) do have a negative d clamp or partial MTPA scaling. - If you‚Äôre comfortable compiling custom firmware, you could edit ‚Äúfw/applications/app_mtpa.c‚Äù or the relevant portion in mcpwm_foc.c to forcibly limit negative id. - For example, something like: if (id < -my_d_current_limit) { id = -my_d_current_limit; } - This is more advanced, but if you or someone in the community codes for the VESC firmware, it‚Äôs feasible to insert. --- ## 3. Final Thoughts - Out-of-the-box: VESC 6.06 lacks a simple ‚ÄúMax Negative D-Axis Current‚Äù slider. - Pragmatic Fix: Try faking lower saliency (foc_motor_ld_lq_diff) or simply reduce total motor amps by ~10‚Äì20%. Coupled with a gentle torque ramp, you‚Äôll probably avoid overcurrent while still enjoying a chunk of MTPA‚Äôs torque boost. - If you crave a more ‚Äúperfect‚Äù negative d clamp, you‚Äôll likely have to patch the source code or find a specialized firmware fork‚Äîso until that lands in official VESC, the best you can do is tune around it. That said, for most high-power builds, even partial MTPA gains are substantial. As long as you keep logs and test carefully, you can strike a balance between big torque and reliable hardware. here is some examples on how you could implement d clamp Below is a minimal, example patch illustrating how you might implement a negative d-axis clamp in the VESC firmware (6.06 or similar). This snippet assumes basic familiarity with building VESC firmware from source and modifying mcpwm_foc.c (or the relevant FOC control file).
[2025-02-22T22:13:41] francois schempers: > Disclaimer > 1. This code is example-only‚Äînot official or guaranteed safe. > 2. The VESC code is released under the GNU GPL v3 license. Make sure any changes you distribute remain GPL-compliant. > 3. Actual line numbers/variable names can differ between firmware versions. You‚Äôll likely need to search for the relevant function(s) (mcpwm_foc_run_filters, mcpwm_foc_control_current, or a portion that calculates MTPA). > 4. Testing on a dev setup (motor on bench, low voltage) is crucial before going full throttle on a high-power build. --- ## 1. Find Where MTPA D‚ÄìQ Currents Are Set In mcpwm_foc.c (around functions that handle the current loops, often near mcpwm_foc_set_idq(), mcpwm_foc_control_current(), or MTPA logic), you‚Äôll see something like: `c // Original logic to set the d and q reference currents float id_set = /* computed or retrieved from MTPA logic */; float iq_set = /* main torque request (q-axis) */; Somewhere after MTPA calculation but before running the final current controller, you can inject a check to clamp negative d-current. For example: // If MTPA or some negative d injection is used // you might see an id_set that goes below a certain negative threshold // Introduce a user-defined clamp, e.g., -d_clamp_value float d_clamp_value = 20.0f; // Example limit in AMPS, tune as needed Then right before the function sets the final id_set, do: // [Pseudo-code snippet] // Some user-defined negative clamp, e.g. -20A // If id_set < -20, we clip it to -20. if (id_set < -d_clamp_value) { id_set = -d_clamp_value; } --- 2. Example Patch Below is a more concrete example. Suppose you define a new parameter conf_general.h or you hard-code it. Let‚Äôs assume you do it inline. You might add something like: // File: mcpwm_foc.c // 1) Add a small ‚Äúuser clamp‚Äù for negative d-axis static float d_axis_neg_clamp = 20.0f; // 20 A negative limit void mcpwm_foc_some_current_logic(float *id_target, float *iq_target) { // ... code computing MTPA, or retrieving id_target from mtpa // For example, if *id_target is negative: if (*id_target < -d_axis_neg_clamp) { *id_target = -d_axis_neg_clamp; } // Then proceed with setting up the FOC control // ... } You‚Äôd call this logic after the MTPA routine that sets d-axis. The exact location differs by version, but typically VESC code does something like: // ... // [MTPA logic in i_d_set, i_q_set] i_d_set = <some negative if using MTPA>; i_q_set = <normal torque command>; // Insert clamp if (i_d_set < -d_axis_neg_clamp) { i_d_set = -d_axis_neg_clamp; } // Then the code goes on to run current controller mcpwm_foc_set_idq(i_d_set, i_q_set); --- 3. Configurability You might want to make d_axis_neg_clamp a real configuration parameter. 1. Put it in the mc_configuration structure. 2. Expose it in conf_general.h or as a new UI field in the VESC Tool. That requires you to do a bit more coding: read from the JSON/app config, store it in the RAM config, etc. So, simplest is just a static float for your personal firmware. --- 4. Additional Notes 1. Units: The clamp is in Amps. Decide what maximum negative Id you can handle‚Äîmaybe 10‚Äì30 A. You‚Äôll have to test in real scenario. 2. Tradeoff: The more you clamp negative d, the less ‚Äúaggressive‚Äù your MTPA torque. 3. Observer Impact: This doesn‚Äôt rewrite the observer itself. The sensorless observer might see slightly different actual d‚Äìq currents, but it‚Äôs typically stable. --- 5. Testing & Verification Steps 1. Low-Voltage Bench Test: Use a small battery or lab supply, spin the motor at partial speed, watch for overcurrent faults. 2. Watch Logs: Confirm the actual id_set never drops below the clamp. 3. Tune: If 20 A is still causing short surges, reduce it to 15 or 10. If it‚Äôs too timid, raise it slightly. --- Final Thoughts
[2025-02-22T22:13:41] francois schempers: This negative d clamp is basically a quick guard rail: ‚ÄúNo matter what MTPA wants, we never set d-axis below -X amps.‚Äù While not an official ‚Äúslider‚Äù in 6.06, the patch above shows where you‚Äôd insert the logic. With it, you can mitigate violent current spikes while still leveraging MTPA‚Äîjust not as far into the negative-d territory. Remember: always keep your ESC‚Äôs thermal and electrical headroom in mind. Even with a clamp, huge torque requests can produce borderline or repeated overcurrent events. Adjusting your overall motor/battery amps, throttle ramp, or motor saliency can further refine things. Good luck hacking the firmware. With careful testing, this snippet can help you keep MTPA workable, safer, and more predictable under VESC 6.06!

[2025-02-23T22:11:25] francois schempers: Below is a concise explanation of why your motor may be saturating (thus limiting current to ~100 A) and a few practical approaches to mitigate that saturation. --- 1. Motor Saturation Explained Magnetic saturation happens when the iron (or ferrite) in the motor‚Äôs stator core reaches a point where it can‚Äôt magnetize any further. At that point, feeding more current does not yield additional torque; instead, energy is lost to heat, and voltage/current waveforms can become distorted. In a typical BLDC hub or outrunner motor: The stator‚Äôs laminations have a certain thickness and quality (silicon steel or similar). When phase current is low or moderate, the stator can guide the magnetic field without issues. At high phase current (e.g., above 100‚Äì120 A in certain motors), the material can saturate, limiting how much additional torque (or current) can flow effectively. --- 2. Why Saturation Limits Motor Current When the motor saturates, the motor‚Äôs inductance actually drops because of the nonlinear magnetic path. This can: 1. Cause excessive current ripple in the windings, forcing the ESC firmware to clamp or reduce actual current to keep safe control loops. 2. Prevent any net torque increase beyond that saturation point‚Äîso even if the ESC tries to push more amps, you won‚Äôt see an actual rise in ‚Äúmeasured motor current‚Äù or real torque output. Thus, from the VESC/Spintend‚Äôs perspective, it might see an overcurrent risk or observe that further command is ‚Äúineffective,‚Äù and the real motor current readout hovers around 100 A, no matter if you request 120‚Äì150 A. --- 3. Possible Solutions 1. Upgrade to a Larger Motor Physical Size/Volume: A physically bigger stator (with more iron mass and/or higher-quality laminations) will saturate at higher currents. Lower kV Winding: Motors with more turns per stator tooth can handle higher phase current before hitting saturation (though it does shift the speed/voltage trade-off). 2. Lower (or Accept) the Phase Current Limit If your motor is saturating at ~100 A, pushing it to 150 A or 200 A seldom yields more torque or performance. You can safely reduce your Motor Current Max in the ESC to ~100‚Äì110 A to avoid wasted energy and potential overcurrent faults. 3. Improve Cooling While more efficient cooling (ferrofluid, hubsinks, better airflow) does not truly raise the magnetic saturation threshold, it can slow down or prevent overheating from near-saturation operation. You may sustain 100 A longer without thermal throttling. If temperature was your limiting factor, better cooling helps. If purely magnetic saturation is the issue, cooling alone won‚Äôt let you surpass that 100 A barrier by much. 4. Magnetic Rework or ‚ÄúBetter Motor Iron‚Äù In extreme DIY, some advanced users might re-laminate or rework stators, but that‚Äôs rarely practical. Easier to pick a motor known for higher current capacity. 5. Check FOC Settings In VESC Tool, ensure your detection is correct‚Äîmisconfigured flux linkage or saturations can mislead the controller, artificially limiting current. Re-run detection or slightly tweak observer gain. If using MTPA or field weakening, big negative d-axis current can force the core deeper into saturation. Disabling or reducing MTPA or FW amplitude sometimes stabilizes higher q-axis current (but at a cost of top speed or torque efficiency). --- 4. Bottom Line If your Spintend 85150 or similar VESC-based ESC is capping around 100 A motor current, the most common reason is that the motor itself physically can‚Äôt handle more before hitting magnetic saturation. To solve it: 1. Use a bigger motor (larger or better stator). 2. Limit your motor current to the saturation point for efficiency. 3. Optimize cooling to maintain performance near saturation current. 4. Double-check your firmware detection and advanced settings so you aren‚Äôt artificially limiting current by an incorrect parameter.
[2025-02-23T22:11:25] francois schempers: This ensures you get maximum stable torque from your existing setup while avoiding wasted energy, overheating, or random cutouts caused by trying to push the motor beyond its magnetic limits.
