[2025-02-24T05:45:55] francois schempers: Q: Is there any way to use traction control depending on the speed and not via ERP?! For example, current-dependent or with an external wheel speed sensor? Since I have two different motors, I also have different ERP, which the TC interprets as spinning. Yes, there are multiple ways to implement traction control without relying solely on electrical RPM (eRPM). The main issue with eRPM-based traction control is that different motors (especially with different KV ratings, winding configurations, or wheel diameters) will produce different eRPM values for the same actual wheel speed. This leads to false slip detection when using a naive eRPM-based approach. Alternative Methods for Traction Control To make traction control more accurate and adaptable, you can use the following methods: 1. Back-EMF Based Traction Control (Internal Method) By comparing the actual back-EMF voltage against the expected voltage (calculated from speed), we can estimate slip without needing an external sensor. This is useful for sensorless operation, where direct wheel speed readings are unavailable. 2. External Wheel Speed Sensor (External Method) A hall-based, optical, or magnetic encoder placed on the wheel can measure actual ground speed. This allows for more reliable slip detection, especially if you have mismatched motors. 3. Current-Based Slip Detection If one motor is drawing significantly more current than expected for a given speed while another motor draws less, this suggests one wheel may be slipping. However, this method is less direct and may require complex filtering. Recommended Approach: Back-EMF Based Traction Control The Back-EMF method provides a built-in, sensorless solution without needing external hardware. Below is a complete implementation that refines traction control using back-EMF voltage as a slip indicator. --- Code: Traction Control Using Back-EMF The following C-based traction control algorithm smooths out back-EMF readings, detects sustained slip events, and adjusts motor current gradually to restore traction. // ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- // Improved Traction Control using Back-EMF // ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- // Tunable Constants ‚Äì Adjust these based on your motor and hardware tests. #define MOTOR_CONSTANT 0.02f // [V/(eRPM)] Converts motor speed (ERPM) to expected back-EMF. #define TRACTION_SLIP_THRESHOLD 0.8f // Slip ratio threshold below which slip is considered occurring. #define TRACTION_MIN_REDUCTION 0.5f // Minimum reduction factor (i.e. never reduce below 50% of original current). #define FILTER_ALPHA 0.1f // Low-pass filter coefficient (0<alpha<1). Lower alpha = slower response. #define SLIP_DETECT_CYCLES 5 // Number of consecutive cycles with slip before engaging traction control. #define CURRENT_RATE_LIMIT 0.05f // Maximum fractional change (per cycle) allowed in current setpoint (e.g. 5%). #define RECOVERY_TIME_CYCLES 10 // Number of cycles to wait before beginning to restore full current. // Global variables (these would typically be members of your motor control data structure) float motor_speed_erpm; // Measured electrical RPM of the motor. float raw_back_emf; // Raw measured back-EMF (in Volts), updated each control cycle. float filtered_back_emf; // Filtered back-EMF value. float original_current_setpoint; // The original desired current (target) setpoint (in Amps). float current_setpoint; // The current commanded motor current (in Amps). bool traction_control_enabled; // Flag to enable or disable traction control. // Internal counters for persistent slip detection and recovery. int slip_counter = 0; // Counts how many consecutive cycles slip condition is detected. int recovery_counter = 0; // Counts cycles since slip condition ended.
[2025-02-24T05:45:55] francois schempers: // ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- // Low-Pass Filter Function // Applies a simple exponential smoothing to reduce noise in the raw back-EMF reading. float lowpass_filter(float previous, float new_val, float alpha) { return (alpha * new_val) + ((1.0f - alpha) * previous); } // ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- // Rate Limiter Function // Gradually adjusts a value (here, current_setpoint) toward a target value // by a maximum fractional step per cycle. float rate_limiter(float current, float target, float rate_limit) { if (current > target) { float diff = current - target; float max_step = original_current_setpoint * rate_limit; if (diff > max_step) return current - max_step; else return target; } else if (current < target) { float diff = target - current; float max_step = original_current_setpoint * rate_limit; if (diff > max_step) return current + max_step; else return target; } return current; } // ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- // update_traction_control() // This function should be called at each control cycle after updating raw sensor // values. It uses a filtered back-EMF measurement and compares it to the expected // back-EMF (calculated from motor speed) to determine if slip is occurring. // It then gradually scales down the current_setpoint if persistent slip is detected, // and slowly restores full current when slip is resolved. void update_traction_control(void) { // 1. Filter the raw back-EMF to smooth out noise. filtered_back_emf = lowpass_filter(filtered_back_emf, raw_back_emf, FILTER_ALPHA); // 2. Calculate the expected back-EMF based on the current motor speed. float expected_back_emf = MOTOR_CONSTANT * motor_speed_erpm; // 3. If expected back-EMF is very low, skip traction control. if (expected_back_emf < 0.1f) { return; } // 4. Compute the slip ratio (filtered measured back-EMF divided by expected back-EMF). float slip_ratio = filtered_back_emf / expected_back_emf; // 5. Traction control logic: if (traction_control_enabled && (slip_ratio < TRACTION_SLIP_THRESHOLD)) { slip_counter++; recovery_counter = 0; if (slip_counter >= SLIP_DETECT_CYCLES) { float reduction_factor = slip_ratio / TRACTION_SLIP_THRESHOLD; if (reduction_factor < TRACTION_MIN_REDUCTION) { reduction_factor = TRACTION_MIN_REDUCTION; } float target_current = original_current_setpoint * reduction_factor; current_setpoint = rate_limiter(current_setpoint, target_current, CURRENT_RATE_LIMIT); } } else { if (slip_counter > 0) { recovery_counter++; if (recovery_counter >= RECOVERY_TIME_CYCLES) { current_setpoint = rate_limiter(current_setpoint, original_current_setpoint, CURRENT_RATE_LIMIT); if (current_setpoint >= original_current_setpoint) { slip_counter = 0; recovery_counter = 0; } } } else { current_setpoint = original_current_setpoint; } } } --- How This Code Works 1. Back-EMF Filtering A low-pass filter smooths the back-EMF readings to remove noise. 2. Slip Detection Logic If filtered back-EMF is significantly lower than expected, it suggests loss of traction. Uses slip_counter to ensure traction control doesn‚Äôt trigger from a single bad reading. 3. Current Reduction Mechanism If slip is detected for multiple cycles, it gradually reduces motor current using a rate limiter to prevent sudden loss of power. 4. Recovery Mechanism If slip stops, it slowly restores full motor current rather than an abrupt jump back. --- Why Use This Over eRPM-Based Traction Control?
[2025-02-24T05:45:56] francois schempers: Works even if you have mismatched motors with different ERPM values. More reliable on slippery surfaces where wheels spin but eRPM fluctuates inconsistently. Doesn‚Äôt require additional sensors, unlike an external wheel encoder. Smoother response, thanks to filtering and gradual recovery. --- Final Considerations If using two motors, apply this logic independently to each motor to prevent mismatches. Test in real conditions, log slip ratios, and adjust TRACTION_SLIP_THRESHOLD. Future improvements could include: Adaptive slip thresholds based on torque demand. Combining current sensing and back-EMF to improve slip detection. This sensorless traction control is a step forward for VESC-based scooters and e-bikes, especially for high-power builds with unevenly matched motors!
[2025-02-24T06:24:43] francois schempers: francois schempers: # üìå Ultimate In-Depth VESC Parameter Guide Use Telegram‚Äôs search to find specific terms like "Field Weakening", "MTPA", "Voltage Cutoff", etc. Structure for each parameter: 1) What It Does ‚Äì Short definition. 2) Deeper Insights ‚Äì Advanced real-world context. 3) How / When to Modify ‚Äì Practical tuning guidelines. 4) Potential Side Effects ‚Äì Common pitfalls or issues. -------------------------------------------------- üîπ 1. PWM & COMMUTATION -------------------------------------------------- üîß 1.1 PWM Mode Param: pwm_mode What It Does ‚Ä¢ The PWM mode to use for BLDC motors. Synchronous is the most tested and recommended mode. ‚Ä¢ Possible Values: Nonsynchronous HISW, Synchronous, Bipolar Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Synchronous ensures both high-side and low-side transistors are used in each switching cycle, often giving better efficiency and lower noise. ‚Ä¢ Nonsynchronous HISW is older: only high-side transistors do PWM, the low-side is fully on or off. ‚Ä¢ Bipolar is typically for specialized or academic contexts. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ Most modern VESC hardware is stable with Synchronous. ‚Ä¢ Only choose Nonsynchronous or Bipolar if your hardware or documentation explicitly recommends it. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Switching Synchronous ‚Üí Nonsynchronous can raise MOSFET temperatures or trigger partial conduction issues at certain duty cycles. ‚Ä¢ Bipolar is untested in many mainstream VESC contexts, so proceed with caution. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 1.2 Commutation Mode Param: comm_mode What It Does ‚Ä¢ Used in BLDC sensorless mode to define how zero-cross detection and commutation timing is handled. ‚Ä¢ Values: Integrate, Delay Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Integrate samples back-EMF continuously after a zero crossing, integrating the waveform. More robust at low speed. ‚Ä¢ Delay is simpler: detect zero-cross, then add a fixed time offset. It‚Äôs less accurate under heavy load. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ Integrate is better for typical e-scooters or e-bikes with frequent low-speed starts. ‚Ä¢ Delay might suffice if your motor rarely sees low RPM or if you prefer a simpler approach. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Delay can lead to stuttering at very low speed or heavier loads. ‚Ä¢ Integrate might require more accurate BEMF coupling parameters from detection. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 1.3 Motor Type Param: motor_type What It Does ‚Ä¢ Chooses the fundamental commutation approach: BLDC (Trapezoidal), DC (brushed motor), or FOC (Field Oriented Control). Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ BLDC = trapezoidal commutation, somewhat louder, slightly less efficient. ‚Ä¢ DC is only for brushed DC motors. Rare in modern setups. ‚Ä¢ FOC is advanced: quieter operation, better torque control, supports field weakening & MTPA. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If the hardware supports it, FOC is usually best for noise & efficiency. ‚Ä¢ BLDC is still used on older or simpler VESC boards. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ If your ESC can‚Äôt handle FOC well, you may see DRV or MOSFET errors at high load or voltage. ‚Ä¢ DC motor mode is irrelevant for typical brushless scooter/e-bike setups. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 1.4 Sensor Mode Param: sensor_mode What It Does ‚Ä¢ Applies only in BLDC mode. Chooses between Sensorless, Sensored, or Hybrid (low speed with sensors, high speed sensorless). Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Hybrid = halls at startup, then reverts to sensorless for efficiency. ‚Ä¢ Pure sensored means halls are used throughout the RPM range. ‚Ä¢ Sensorless is for motors without sensors or if you prefer no hall wiring. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ For a BLDC build with hall sensors, Hybrid is recommended for smooth takeoff. ‚Ä¢ If no hall sensors exist, sensorless is your only option. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Sensorless can cause rough startup on heavy loads. ‚Ä¢ Sensored-only might have overhead or timing offsets at high RPM, but it‚Äôs minor in practice. -------------------------------------------------- üîπ 2. CURRENT & BATTERY LIMITS --------------------------------------------------
[2025-02-24T06:24:43] francois schempers: üîß 2.1 Motor Current Max Param: l_current_max What It Does ‚Ä¢ Maximum positive (forward) phase current into the motor. Defines peak torque. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Phase current can exceed battery current at partial throttle due to duty cycle step-down. ‚Ä¢ Setting too high can overheat the motor or saturate the ESC‚Äôs thermal limits. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ Check motor‚Äôs continuous & peak ratings. ‚Ä¢ Watch motor temperature on test rides before going higher. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Excessively high = thermal runaway in motor windings or ESC MOSFET burnouts. ‚Ä¢ Too low = weak acceleration, under-utilized motor. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 2.2 Motor Current Max Brake Param: l_current_min (negative) What It Does ‚Ä¢ Maximum negative phase current (braking torque). The energy from braking goes back to the ESC and potentially the battery. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Large negative phase current can generate very strong braking torque even if your battery regen limit is smaller. The difference is dissipated as heat in MOSFETs. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ Increase negativity if you want stronger e-brake. ‚Ä¢ If your hardware or motor overheats on repeated downhills, reduce it. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Overstress of the ESC if the negative phase current is too high. ‚Ä¢ If battery can‚Äôt accept that much regen, you might see BMS cut or overvoltage fault. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 2.3 Battery Current Max Param: l_in_current_max What It Does ‚Ä¢ The maximum drawn from the battery side. Major factor in your ‚Äúforward‚Äù power limit. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ This must respect your BMS or cell‚Äôs discharge capability (continuous/peak). ‚Ä¢ The battery current is usually lower than the motor current except at high duty cycles. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If your BMS is rated 60A, set ~60A here. ‚Ä¢ If your battery is large and robust, you can push it higher. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Battery or BMS overload if set too high, triggering abrupt BMS cut mid-ride. ‚Ä¢ If set too low, your top speed might still be fine at high duty, but acceleration will be limited. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 2.4 Battery Current Max Regen Param: l_in_current_min (negative) What It Does ‚Ä¢ Maximum negative battery current. Limits how much regenerative current is fed back into the battery. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ If your battery can handle 10A charging, set about -10A. ‚Ä¢ This is separate from motor braking current max: the ESC will limit battery current accordingly. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If your BMS or cells can handle more charge current, you can set a bigger negative number for stronger regen. ‚Ä¢ If your battery is frequently near full, high regen can cause overvoltage. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ If set too negative, you risk BMS triggers or cell damage from large charge bursts. ‚Ä¢ If set not negative enough, your regen braking power is minimal. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 2.5 Input Current Limit Map Start Param: l_in_current_map_start What It Does ‚Ä¢ Tells the ESC to begin limiting Q-axis current once battery current hits some fraction (like 80‚Äì90%) of max input current. Default is 1.0 (off). Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Helpful if you do field weakening or MTPA and see battery current overshoots near top speed. ‚Ä¢ E.g., setting 0.8 means at 80% of battery limit, it starts restricting additional torque. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If your logs show battery current spikes to 100% instantaneously causing oscillation, set around 0.8 or 0.9. ‚Ä¢ If no issues, leaving it at 1 is fine. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ If set too low, you artificially reduce max power well before full capacity. ‚Ä¢ If set too high, you might see minor current oscillations at top-end. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 2.6 Input Current Map Filter Param: l_in_current_map_filter What It Does ‚Ä¢ A filtering constant (0‚Äì1) that smooths battery current data before applying Q-axis limit in the ‚Äúmap start‚Äù feature.
[2025-02-24T06:24:43] francois schempers: Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ A smaller number (0.005) = heavier smoothing. ‚Ä¢ A bigger (0.1) = minimal filtering, more real-time reaction but can be noisy. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you see ‚Äúhunting‚Äù or surging at high speed, use heavier filtering (like 0.005‚Äì0.01). ‚Ä¢ If you need snappier response, go higher. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Too much filtering can let short battery spikes slip through. ‚Ä¢ Too little filtering can cause torque pulsing near the limit. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 2.7 Absolute Maximum Current Param: l_abs_current_max What It Does ‚Ä¢ A hard fault threshold. If current magnitude exceeds this, the ESC disables output instantly. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Typically set higher than normal to avoid nuisance trips from short spikes (150‚Äì300A, for instance). How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you get random ABS_OVER_CURRENT faults, either raise this or enable slow filtering (l_slow_abs_current). ‚Ä¢ Keep it sufficiently above your normal current to handle transients. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Setting it too high can let a real short-circuit go on longer, risking hardware damage. ‚Ä¢ Setting it too low = repeated overcurrent faults on normal spikes. -------------------------------------------------- üîπ 3. RPM & DUTY LIMITS -------------------------------------------------- üîß 3.1 Max ERPM Reverse Param: l_min_erpm What It Does ‚Ä¢ Maximum negative electrical RPM if reversing is allowed. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ For no reverse, set 0. ‚Ä¢ For partial reverse, set a negative eRPM that matches desired reverse speed. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ Most e-scooters do not use reverse: set it 0 if you want to disable reversing. ‚Ä¢ For small vehicles needing reverse, pick a negative limit aligned with safe speeds. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ If reversing is enabled but user is unaware, accidental negative throttle can jerk you backward. ‚Ä¢ Large negative eRPM can cause mechanical stress if you force full speed reverse. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 3.2 Max ERPM Param: l_max_erpm What It Does ‚Ä¢ The maximum electrical RPM. The ESC enforces a speed cap. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ eRPM = mechanical RPM √ó number_of_pole_pairs. ‚Ä¢ E.g., 14 magnet motor => 7 pole pairs, so 6000 mechanical RPM => 42000 eRPM. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you want an artificial top-speed limit, reduce it from your default. ‚Ä¢ If you have a large motor that can spin beyond 100k eRPM, set a suitably high number. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ If too low, you‚Äôll never reach your mechanical potential. ‚Ä¢ Hard limit can feel abrupt if l_erpm_start is high (like 0.95 or 1.0 fraction). -------------------------------------------------- üîß 3.3 ERPM Limit Start Param: l_erpm_start What It Does ‚Ä¢ The fraction of l_max_erpm where the current begins to ramp down. So 0.8 means at 80% of max eRPM, torque is gradually limited. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ This yields a soft approach to top speed rather than an abrupt cutoff. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ 0.8 is typical if you want a smoother cap. ‚Ä¢ 1.0 means no soft zone: a harsh limit near max eRPM. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ If set too low (like 0.5), you lose mid-range power unnecessarily. ‚Ä¢ If set 1.0, the cutoff can be jarring. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 3.4 Max ERPM Full Brake / Max ERPM Full Brake Current Control Param: l_max_erpm_fbrake, l_max_erpm_fbrake_cc What It Does ‚Ä¢ BLDC-specific parameters for controlling or disallowing a full brake or direction change below certain ERPM thresholds. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Typically used if you allow reversing in BLDC mode. ‚Ä¢ In FOC, these are generally ignored or less relevant. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you don‚Äôt plan on reversing, default is fine. ‚Ä¢ If you do reversing, be sure you set safe speeds for direction changes. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Setting them too high can let you attempt direction reversals at dangerous speeds in BLDC. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 3.5 Minimum Input Voltage / Maximum Input Voltage Params: l_min_vin, l_max_vin What It Does ‚Ä¢ ESC throws fault if supply voltage is below min or above max.
[2025-02-24T06:24:43] francois schempers: Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ For 36/42V nominal, a typical max is 57V. ‚Ä¢ For 72V setups (84V full), you must raise l_max_vin to ~90‚Äì95V. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ Always match your battery‚Äôs highest charge voltage plus margin. ‚Ä¢ Set l_min_vin slightly below your normal cutoff. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ If l_max_vin is too low for a 20S battery, you‚Äôll get Over_Voltage fault at full charge. ‚Ä¢ If l_min_vin is too high, you get Under_Voltage cutout even if battery is still partially usable. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 3.6 Battery Voltage Cutoff Start / End Params: l_battery_cut_start, l_battery_cut_end What It Does ‚Ä¢ Gradually reduces motor power as voltage nears the cutoff. Full braking is still allowed. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Example: For 10S Li-ion, set start ~34V, end ~30V. ‚Ä¢ This helps avoid abrupt BMS cut. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ Base on your cell‚Äôs recommended min voltage (like 3.0V/cell for Li-ion). ‚Ä¢ If your BMS cuts at 2.8V/cell, set a slightly higher end for safety. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ If set too high, you lose performance with significant capacity left. ‚Ä¢ If too low, you risk damaging cells or hitting BMS cutoff anyway. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 3.7 Battery Voltage Regen Cutoff Start / End Params: l_battery_regen_cut_start, l_battery_regen_cut_end What It Does ‚Ä¢ Similar concept but for regenerative braking on a full battery to prevent overcharge. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ For a 20S battery (84V fully charged), you might set start=82V, end=84V. ‚Ä¢ If left default (1000 & 1100), it never triggers, risking overvoltage on steep downhills with full charge. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ Set according to your pack‚Äôs max voltage. ‚Ä¢ If you live in hilly areas, ensure this is correct or BMS may force a dangerous cutoff mid-brake. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ If start is set too low, you rarely get regen. ‚Ä¢ If not configured, you could blow the BMS or see ‚ÄúOverVoltage‚Äù faults at full battery. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 3.8 Slow ABS Current Limit Param: l_slow_abs_current What It Does ‚Ä¢ Uses a filtered measurement for the absolute max current fault, preventing triggers on very short spikes. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ If you frequently see ‚ÄúABS_OVER_CURRENT‚Äù on fast throttle changes, this can help. ‚Ä¢ Great for large inductive motors or big short bursts. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If random overcurrent faults appear with no real sustained high current, enable or keep it on. ‚Ä¢ If you truly want immediate fault on any spike, keep it off. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ If you rely on the absolute max to protect hardware from short, you might allow small spikes. Usually harmless for typical usage though. -------------------------------------------------- üîπ 4. THERMAL PARAMETERS -------------------------------------------------- üîß 4.1 MOSFET Temp Cutoff Start / End Params: l_temp_fet_start, l_temp_fet_end What It Does ‚Ä¢ The ESC reduces output current once the MOSFET temperature hits ‚Äústart‚Äù, fully shutting down or faulting at ‚Äúend‚Äù. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Default often 85¬∞C start, 100¬∞C end. Some hardware can go 110‚Äì120¬∞C safely, verify specs. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you have big heatsinks or forced cooling, you can push it higher (90/110). ‚Ä¢ In hot climates or limited cooling, keep a safer margin. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Setting too high can degrade MOSFETs or let them approach meltdown. ‚Ä¢ Setting too low leads to frequent thermal throttling when it might still be safe. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 4.2 Motor Temp Cutoff Start / End Params: l_temp_motor_start, l_temp_motor_end What It Does ‚Ä¢ If the motor has a temperature sensor, it lowers motor current at start, then full fault at end. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Some motors have an NTC (10k or 100k) or PTC sensor. Others have none, so these do nothing. ‚Ä¢ Typical start ~85¬∞C, end ~100¬∞C or 110¬∞C, depending on magnet grade. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If your motor is high-grade (120¬∞C capable), you can set 100‚Äì120¬∞C as the end. ‚Ä¢ Watch logs to see if you approach these thresholds.
[2025-02-24T06:24:43] francois schempers: Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ If set incorrectly low, you lose power even though the motor can handle more. ‚Ä¢ If set too high, you risk permanent magnet damage or winding insulation issues. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 4.3 Acceleration Temperature Decrease Param: l_temp_accel_dec What It Does ‚Ä¢ Decrease MOSFET/motor temperature limits by a percentage during acceleration, preserving some headroom for braking torque. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ If set to 0.15 (15%), then under acceleration, your 100¬∞C limit effectively becomes ~85¬∞C. Once you release acceleration, you get full limit again. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you do repeated accelerate-brake cycles and want guaranteed braking torque left, keep it around 0.15‚Äì0.2. ‚Ä¢ If you rarely need that, set 0 for no difference. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Too high = acceleration is thermally limited early, sacrificing performance. ‚Ä¢ 0 can lead to strong acceleration but no safety margin for braking if near temp limit. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 4.4 Minimum Duty Cycle / Maximum Duty Cycle Params: l_min_duty, l_max_duty What It Does ‚Ä¢ Forces a clamp on the PWM modulation ratio. For instance, max 0.95 means the ESC never hits full 100% duty. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Some designs do l_max_duty=0.95 or 0.99 to avoid saturating sampling windows. ‚Ä¢ l_min_duty=0.005 is default so you can release to near zero torque. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you want maximum possible speed, set ~0.99. Check hardware stability near 100% duty. ‚Ä¢ If motor stalling issues at zero, raising l_min_duty slightly might help. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Setting max_duty=1.0 can cause issues with current sampling if your hardware can‚Äôt handle near 100% well. ‚Ä¢ High min_duty can produce a ‚Äúpush‚Äù at idle, not fully freewheeling. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 4.5 Maximum Wattage / Maximum Braking Wattage Params: l_watt_max, l_watt_min What It Does ‚Ä¢ A power-based limit on output or braking. Usually overshadowed by current-based limits. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Some e-bike regulations want 250W or 750W nominal. This tries to enforce it, but dynamic conditions can still spike currents. ‚Ä¢ If set very high, it effectively does nothing. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If local laws or personal preferences require a watt cap, set accordingly. ‚Ä¢ If you want no power-based cap, leave them near default (1.5e6 W). Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Pure watt-limiting can behave oddly with partial duty cycles or hills. ‚Ä¢ If braking wattage is also limited, you might lose needed braking force. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 4.6 Max Current Scale / Min Current Scale Params: l_current_max_scale, l_current_min_scale What It Does ‚Ä¢ Multipliers that scale your current limits on-the-fly without rewriting them permanently. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ 1.0 means no scale. 0.5 means half your configured max or min current effectively. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you want an ‚Äúeco mode‚Äù at half torque, set 0.5. ‚Ä¢ If you only run one profile, keep it 1.0. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Forgetting these are not at 1 can cause confusion about why you have low torque or weak brakes. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 4.7 Duty Cycle Current Limit Start Param: l_duty_start What It Does ‚Ä¢ At high duty cycle, the motor can approach battery voltage. This param sets at which duty fraction the ESC starts limiting current. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ 1.0 means no limit. If your hardware or motor saturates near 90‚Äì95% duty, you might set 0.9 so you never truly saturate. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If your motor or ESC acts strangely near full duty, set 0.9 or 0.95. ‚Ä¢ If stable at 100% duty, keep it at 1.0. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Lowering it to 0.8 or 0.85 can reduce top-speed torque in that last portion of the duty range. ‚Ä¢ If you do advanced field weakening, you might keep it at 1.0 and let FW handle it. -------------------------------------------------- üîπ 5. BLDC SENSORLESS (BLDC-Mode Specific) --------------------------------------------------
[2025-02-24T06:24:43] francois schempers: Many people use FOC, so this is only relevant if you specifically run BLDC sensorless. üîß 5.1 Minimum ERPM, Min ERPM Cycle Int Limit, Max Brake Current at Direction Change ‚Ä¢ Control how the ESC transitions to open-loop or prevents reversing at certain currents in BLDC mode. ‚Ä¢ Typically set automatically or by detection. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ If stuttering at low RPM, experiment with these or re-detect your motor constants. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Wrong settings can cause stalling or rough commutation at low speeds. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 5.2 Cycle Integrator Limit, Phase Advance, BEMF Coupling Params: sl_cycle_int_limit, sl_phase_advance_at_br, sl_bemf_coupling_k, etc. What They Do ‚Ä¢ Define the zero-cross detection method and commutation timing in BLDC sensorless. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Usually set by detection. ‚Ä¢ If you have an unusual motor (very high KV or very low), manual tuning might help. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Incorrect values => early or late commutation => large noise, stutter, or poor efficiency. -------------------------------------------------- üîπ 6. FOC PARAMETERS -------------------------------------------------- üîß 6.1 Current KP / KI Params: foc_current_kp, foc_current_ki What It Does ‚Ä¢ The D/Q current controller gains in FOC. ‚Ä¢ Typically found automatically by the ‚Äúdetection‚Äù procedure. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ If KP is too high, you might get overshoot or audible squeals. ‚Ä¢ If KI is too high, drifting or low-frequency hunting can occur. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If detection is stable, no need to tweak. ‚Ä¢ If you see ‚ÄúABS OverCurrent‚Äù or poor torque response, try lowering KP or re-running detection. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Wrong gains = serious stutter, noise, or slow current loop response. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 6.2 Zero Vector Frequency Param: foc_f_zv What It Does ‚Ä¢ The fundamental switching frequency for SVM zero vectors in FOC. ‚Ä¢ Typically 20‚Äì30 kHz to stay above audible hearing range. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Going to 30 kHz can make the drive silent but raises switching losses and CPU load. ‚Ä¢ 25 kHz is a common compromise. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you hear a whine at 20 kHz, try 30 kHz. ‚Ä¢ If your hardware overheats at 30 kHz, step down to 20‚Äì25 kHz. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ High f_zv => extra MOSFET heat, potential CPU overhead. ‚Ä¢ Low f_zv => audible noise. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 6.3 Dead Time Compensation Param: foc_dt_us What It Does ‚Ä¢ Compensates for the small off period between high and low MOSFET conduction. ‚Ä¢ Typically ~0.08‚Äì0.2 ¬µs on many designs. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Proper compensation yields smoother torque at low speed. ‚Ä¢ Overcompensation can cause negative torque or offset. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ Usually auto-detected or based on hardware suggestions. ‚Ä¢ If you suspect poor low-speed performance, tweak in small increments. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Setting it wrong => stuttering or minor torque inefficiency at very low speeds. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 6.4 Encoder Inverted / Offset / Ratio Params: foc_encoder_inverted, foc_encoder_offset, foc_encoder_ratio What It Does ‚Ä¢ For an external encoder (ABI, etc.), define orientation, offset degrees, ratio of mechanical to electrical rotations. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ For a 14-pole motor with an encoder on the shaft, ratio might be 7. ‚Ä¢ If the motor spins backward, toggling invert or offset can fix it. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ After detection, if the angle is 180¬∞ off, invert or shift offset. ‚Ä¢ If a gear is in between, set ratio accordingly. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Wrong offset or ratio => the ESC can‚Äôt track rotor, leading to stalling or rough motion. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 6.5 Sensor Mode (FOC) Param: foc_sensor_mode What It Does ‚Ä¢ For FOC, chooses ‚ÄúSensorless, Encoder, Hall Sensors, HFI, VSS, 45 Deg HFI, Coupled HFI,‚Äù etc. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Hall Sensors = instant start with no guess. ‚Ä¢ HFI or VSS helps sensorless start from 0 rpm if the motor has enough saliency.
[2025-02-24T06:24:43] francois schempers: How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you have physical halls, choose ‚ÄúHall Sensors.‚Äù ‚Ä¢ If sensorless is desired with high torque from standstill, consider 45 Deg V0V7 HFI or Coupled HFI. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ HFI is more CPU-intensive and can fail if Ld‚âàLq with low saliency. ‚Ä¢ Hall-based might skip if the signals are noisy at high speed. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 6.6 Speed Tracker Kp / Ki Params: foc_pll_kp, foc_pll_ki What It Does ‚Ä¢ Gains for the speed observer in FOC. Usually 2000 / 30000 by default. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ If you see speed readout delay or overshoot, tweak. ‚Ä¢ Usually no need to change unless advanced debugging. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ Double or halve them if you suspect observer ‚Äúlag‚Äù or ‚Äúnoise.‚Äù Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Overly big = speed reading hunts or flickers. ‚Ä¢ Too small = slow response in the speed estimate. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 6.7 Motor Inductance, Lq-Ld Diff, Resistance, Flux Linkage Params: foc_motor_l, foc_motor_ld_lq_diff, foc_motor_r, foc_motor_flux_linkage What It Does ‚Ä¢ Fundamental motor parameters for FOC. Usually auto-detected. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ For IPM motors, Ld ‚â† Lq. That difference enables MTPA. ‚Ä¢ If detection is off, you get poor torque or observer misalignment. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ Usually detection is fine. If a weird motor, you might measure manually with ‚Äúmeasure_res/ind‚Äù in VESC Tool. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Wrong values => stuttering, huge current spikes, or inaccurate field weakening behavior. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 6.8 Observer Gain / Slow Gain Params: foc_observer_gain, foc_observer_gain_slow What It Does ‚Ä¢ Controls how strongly the sensorless FOC observer tracks rotor angle. ‚Ä¢ If too high, overshoot. If too low, lag. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Gains ~ your motor‚Äôs L, R, flux. ‚Ä¢ Lower slow gain can help at low duty cycles. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If big cogging or losing sync at certain speeds, try halving the main observer_gain. ‚Ä¢ If everything is stable, no changes needed. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Not enough gain => no reliable torque at low speed. ‚Ä¢ Too much => random current or angle spikes. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 6.9 Duty Downramp Kp / Ki Params: foc_duty_dowmramp_kp, foc_duty_dowmramp_ki What It Does ‚Ä¢ In ‚Äúduty cycle mode‚Äù (rare usage), prevents current overshoot when throttle is reduced quickly. Not used much in standard current control. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ If purely in ‚Äúcurrent control mode,‚Äù these might be irrelevant. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If duty-based control is your mode, adjust to avoid big spikes on throttle release. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Overly large gains => slow speed decrease. ‚Ä¢ Too small => abrupt current surges. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 6.10 Start Current Decrease / Openloop Settings Params: foc_start_curr_dec, foc_openloop_rpm, etc. What It Does ‚Ä¢ For sensorless FOC, you can do partial open-loop at start, limiting the current to avoid saturating the observer. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ If your motor saturates easily at 0 rpm, a big current can ruin observer tracking. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If stalling or big jerk at zero speed, set a start_curr_dec < 1 or add some openloop ramp time. ‚Ä¢ If stable, keep default. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Lower start current means weaker launches. ‚Ä¢ 1.0 means no reduction but might cause stutter at heavy load zero speed. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 6.11 MTPA Algorithm Mode Param: foc_mtpa_mode What It Does ‚Ä¢ Allows negative d-axis current for IPM motors, improving torque-per-amp. ‚Ä¢ Values: Disabled, IQ Target, IQ Measured Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ IPM motors have Ld < Lq. MTPA can significantly boost torque. ‚Ä¢ IQ Measured can be more reactive but noisier. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you have a known IPM motor (like many QS hub motors), enable MTPA. ‚Ä¢ Try IQ Target first, or IQ Measured if transitions feel off.
[2025-02-24T06:24:44] francois schempers: Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Negative d-current can raise motor‚Äôs back-EMF at sudden fault events => high bus voltage risk. ‚Ä¢ If Ld = Lq, MTPA is pointless. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 6.12 Field Weakening Params: foc_fw_current_max, foc_fw_duty_start, etc. What It Does ‚Ä¢ Injects negative d-axis current at high speed to exceed base motor speed. Increases top RPM but with caution. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Great for ‚Äúoverdrive‚Äù ~10‚Äì30% more speed. ‚Ä¢ Watch for overvoltage if throttle is cut at high RPM. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ For 5‚Äì30A FW as a start, set duty_start ~0.9. ‚Ä¢ Validate logs on actual rides. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Excessive FW => bus volt spikes, MOSFET damage, or battery BMS triggers. ‚Ä¢ Motor might overheat if run at high speed heavily. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 6.13 Speed Tracker Position Source Param: foc_speed_soure What It Does ‚Ä¢ Position source for the speed trackers: ‚ÄúCorrected Position‚Äù vs. ‚ÄúObserver‚Äù only. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ If you have sensors or HFI, corrected uses that data. ‚Ä¢ Observer might drift slightly at 0 speed but can be smoother at high speed. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you see speed bounce from sensor noise, pick ‚ÄúObserver.‚Äù ‚Ä¢ If observer lags at very low speed, ‚ÄúCorrected‚Äù might help. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ With poor sensor data, ‚ÄúCorrected‚Äù can degrade. ‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúObserver‚Äù alone might have small offset at near-zero. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 6.14 Short Low-Side FETs on Zero Duty Param: foc_short_ls_on_zero_duty What It Does ‚Ä¢ When duty=0 in FOC, the ESC can short the motor windings via the low-side MOSFETs or leave them open. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Shorting can create mild braking torque at zero & reduce driver power. ‚Ä¢ Leaving them open gives freewheel. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you want less rolling at 0 throttle, enable short. ‚Ä¢ If you want free coasting, disable. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Could concentrate heat on the low-side MOSFETs. ‚Ä¢ Slight drag if short is active. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 6.15 Overmodulation Factor Param: foc_overmod_factor What It Does ‚Ä¢ Allows SVM to exceed 100% modulation, e.g., hexagonal wave up to 1.15. Gains slight speed without full field weakening. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ 1.0‚Äì1.15 typical. ‚Ä¢ 1.15 approaches trapezoidal-like conduction at high speed. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you want a small top-speed bump, try 1.05‚Äì1.10. ‚Ä¢ At 1.0, no overmod. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Slightly rougher waveforms = more motor heat or noise at top speed. -------------------------------------------------- üîπ 7. SPEED & POSITION PID -------------------------------------------------- üîß 7.1 PID Loop Rate Param: sp_pid_loop_rate What It Does ‚Ä¢ Rate for position & speed controllers. Values: 25Hz to 10000Hz. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Higher = more CPU load but faster response. ‚Ä¢ 250‚Äì1000Hz is typical for e-scooter. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If speed-limiting feels laggy, increase. ‚Ä¢ If CPU is overwhelmed, reduce. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Too high => stuttering if CPU can‚Äôt keep up. ‚Ä¢ Too low => slow reaction to load changes. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 7.2 Speed PID Kp, Ki, Kd, Filter Params: s_pid_kp, s_pid_ki, s_pid_kd, s_pid_kd_filter What It Does ‚Ä¢ The speed controller in VESC, layered over the current controller. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Usually small because the underlying current loop is already fast. ‚Ä¢ High Kp can overshoot or surge around target speed. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you see big oscillations near set speed, reduce Kp or add Kd. ‚Ä¢ If it‚Äôs too slow to respond to hills, raise Kp/Ki carefully. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Excessive gains => jerkiness or noise. ‚Ä¢ Too low => sluggish speed corrections. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 7.3 Minimum ERPM, Allow Braking, Ramp eRPM Params: s_pid_min_erpm, s_pid_allow_braking, s_pid_ramp_erpms_s What It Does ‚Ä¢ Additional rules for speed control: no speed PID below min ERPM, whether braking is permitted, how fast the speed reference can ramp.
[2025-02-24T06:24:44] francois schempers: Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ If allow_braking is off, the speed controller never commands negative torque. ‚Ä¢ Ramp_erpms_s is how quickly the speed setpoint can climb. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ For typical e-scooter usage, keep braking on. ‚Ä¢ If you want a soft spool-up in speed mode, define a ramp limit (e.g., 25000 erpms/s). Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Disabling braking in speed PID = no slowing under speed commands, coasts downhill. ‚Ä¢ Overly small ramp => slow acceleration requests from the speed loop. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 7.4 Speed Source Param: s_pid_speed_source What It Does ‚Ä¢ PLL vs. Fast / Faster Estimator for deriving speed in the speed PID. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ PLL is stable but slightly slower. ‚Ä¢ Fast or Faster can be more immediate but noisier. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you want crisp speed-limiting and can handle some noise, pick fast. ‚Ä¢ If you prefer stable readouts, pick PLL. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Too noisy => torque oscillations or speed readout jitter. ‚Ä¢ Too slow => mild speed-limiting lag. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 7.5 Position PID Params: p_pid_kp, p_pid_ki, p_pid_kd, etc. What It Does ‚Ä¢ For servo-like position control applications. Less common for e-scooters. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Typically used in robotics/CNC. ‚Ä¢ If you only do speed or current control, you may ignore this. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Overly high gains => severe oscillations. ‚Ä¢ Usually not relevant for normal PEV usage. -------------------------------------------------- üîπ 8. CURRENT CONTROL (BLDC/DC) -------------------------------------------------- üîß 8.1 Startup Boost Param: cc_startup_boost_duty What It Does ‚Ä¢ In BLDC/DC current control, it‚Äôs the minimum duty fraction when throttle is first engaged, to ensure some torque at zero speed. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ If 0.02, you get a mild ‚Äújump.‚Äù ‚Ä¢ Too high and it can jerk from standstill. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If your motor has trouble launching from zero, raise slightly. ‚Ä¢ If you want gentler starts, lower it. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Too big => unstoppable jump from standstill. ‚Ä¢ Too small => possible stalling under load. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 8.2 Minimum Current Param: cc_min_current What It Does ‚Ä¢ The threshold below which the ESC stops driving in BLDC/DC current mode, effectively releasing the motor. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ If set 0.1A, you might have a small idle hold. ‚Ä¢ If 0.01, it‚Äôs basically free-coasting under that level. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you want a bit of ‚Äúhold‚Äù at near-zero throttle, raise. ‚Ä¢ If you want full freewheel, keep it very low. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Larger min current wastes energy or creates mild forward push at minimal throttle. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 8.3 cc_gain, cc_ramp_step_max ‚Ä¢ Additional BLDC/DC current control parameters for ramping the duty cycle under load. ‚Ä¢ Typically 0.0046 for cc_gain, 0.04 for cc_ramp_step_max. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ If you have a super low inductance motor, you might reduce cc_gain. ‚Ä¢ If acceleration is jerky, tweak ramp_step. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Wrong gain => overshoot or sluggish throttle response in BLDC/DC mode. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 8.4 Fault Stop Time / Duty Ramp Step Params: m_fault_stop_time_ms, m_duty_ramp_step What It Does ‚Ä¢ How long the motor is disabled after a fault. ‚Ä¢ The max ramp step in duty mode for BLDC/DC. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Typical fault stop is 500 ms. ‚Ä¢ If you want quick auto-recovery, you can reduce it. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Too short => repeated fault triggers rapidly. ‚Ä¢ Too long => annoying downtime if a minor fault occurs. -------------------------------------------------- üîπ 9. ENCODERS & SENSOR PORTS -------------------------------------------------- üîß 9.1 Encoder Counts, Sin/Cos Gains, Offsets ‚Ä¢ For advanced encoders: specify amplitude ~1.0, offsets ~1.65 V for sin/cos, etc. ‚Ä¢ If you see weird offset, correct it here.
[2025-02-24T06:24:44] francois schempers: Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Wrong offset => angle errors, stutter. ‚Ä¢ Wrong amplitude => poor angle resolution. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 9.2 Sensor Port Mode Param: m_sensor_port_mode What It Does ‚Ä¢ Mode for the sensor port: Hall, ABI, AS5047, Sin/Cos, TS5700N8501, BISSC, etc. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Must match your physical sensor wiring or you get garbage signals. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ If you pick AS5047 but physically have halls, no reading. ‚Ä¢ Some sensors need advanced or different wiring. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 9.3 Invert Motor Direction Param: m_invert_direction What It Does ‚Ä¢ Flips the commanded direction in software. Alternative to swapping two motor phases physically. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Great if detection found reversed rotation or if dual-motor setups need opposite directions on front vs. rear. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ If you rely on directional logic for braking or reversing, ensure you also account for inverted direction. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 9.4 DRV8301 OC Mode / DRV8301 OC Adjustment ‚Ä¢ For DRV8301-based hardware, define how hardware overcurrent protection is triggered or latched. ‚Ä¢ Usually "Current Limit" is standard. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ If the oc_adj is set too low, you get easy fault triggers. ‚Ä¢ If too high, real shorts might not be interrupted fast enough. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 9.5 Min/Max Switching Frequency in BLDC Params: m_bldc_f_sw_min, m_bldc_f_sw_max What It Does ‚Ä¢ If using adaptive switching in BLDC, it can move between min & max freq. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Default range ~3 kHz to 35 kHz. ‚Ä¢ Lower freq => audible noise, higher => more heat in MOSFETs. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Too high freq on old boards => driver errors or MOSFET overheating. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 9.6 Beta Value for Motor Thermistor, etc. Param: m_ntc_motor_beta, m_ptc_motor_coeff, etc. What It Does ‚Ä¢ If the motor has an NTC or PTC sensor, set the correct beta or coefficient. ‚Ä¢ Some motors use KTY or PT1000. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ Wrong sensor settings => inaccurate temperature reading => poor thermal throttling. -------------------------------------------------- üîπ 10. BMS SETTINGS -------------------------------------------------- üîß 10.1 BMS Type Param: bms.type What It Does ‚Ä¢ If using a CAN-based ‚ÄúVESC BMS,‚Äù you can unify data. If none, ignore. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúNone‚Äù means the ESC ignores BMS comm. ‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúVESC BMS‚Äù uses messages from the official hardware or similar. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ If incorrectly enabled, you might see spurious limiting if no real BMS data is present. -------------------------------------------------- üîß 10.2 BMS Limit Mode, Temperature Limit, SOC, VCell Min/Max Params under bms.* What It Does ‚Ä¢ The ESC can reduce current smoothly based on battery‚Äôs temperature, SOC, or cell voltages from the BMS over CAN. Deeper Insights ‚Ä¢ Overtemp or low SOC => input current is scaled down. ‚Ä¢ This prevents abrupt BMS cut at cell-level constraints. How / When to Modify ‚Ä¢ If you have an advanced BMS that shares data, set these for gentle limiting. ‚Ä¢ If your BMS is standalone or simple, these do nothing. Potential Side Effects ‚Ä¢ If BMS data is invalid or missing, the ESC might clamp power incorrectly. ‚Ä¢ Misconfigured voltage or SOC limits can hamper performance or cause weird cutouts. -------------------------------------------------- # WRAP-UP & FINAL NOTES ‚Ä¢ Always Start with Detection: Let the firmware auto-detect motor parameters (R, L, flux, hall table, etc.). ‚Ä¢ Test in Steps: Increase or adjust current limits incrementally, watching temperature logs. ‚Ä¢ Thermal & Voltage Headroom: Large negative braking or field weakening can produce bus voltage spikes. Ensure safety margins.
[2025-02-24T06:24:44] francois schempers: ‚Ä¢ Hall vs Sensorless vs HFI: - Hall = simpler immediate start, - Sensorless/HFI = advanced but can be just as good if tuned well, - Keep an eye on noise or offset at high speeds. ‚Ä¢ Smart BMS: If you have a CAN-based BMS, you can coordinate battery info for smooth limiting. If not, the ESC only sees battery voltage and can‚Äôt individually protect cell groups. Ride Safely and enjoy the benefits of a finely tuned VESC-based controller. If something behaves oddly, revert to your last known stable config. Detailed logs are your friend!
[2025-02-24T06:25:50] francois schempers: VESC parameters Guide Review & Validation Process Hey everyone! I've put together a detailed guide on each VESC parameter, and I‚Äôm sharing it here so we can double-check everything before final validation and lockout. The goal is to ensure the guide is as accurate, clear, and useful as possible before it gets finalized. If you find errors, missing details, or have improvements to suggest, now‚Äôs the time! Once the guide is complete, it will be locked to prevent further edits and ensure consistency. üí° Contributions Matter! Significant improvements will be credited in the final version, so if your input helps refine the guide, you'll be acknowledged for it. Thanks in advance for your feedback! Let‚Äôs make this the best VESC resource possible. üöÄ

[2025-02-27T20:35:45] JPPL: Floaty app
[2025-02-27T20:35:53] JPPL: Install floaty or refloat package
[2025-02-27T20:36:02] Smart Repair: Can anyone confirm that the script would work? #include <HardwareSerial.h> #include "VescUart.h" // UART interface for the VESC HardwareSerial vescSerial(1); VescUart vesc; // Button pin const int buttonPin = 0; bool lastButtonState = HIGH; bool profile = false; // Profile state (false = Profile 1, true = Profile 2) // VESC IDs (Master = 0, Slave = 1) const int masterID = 0; const int slaveID = 1; // Profile 1 values const int rpmMaster1 = 2000; // Master VESC (e.g., 22 km/h) const int powerMaster1 = 1250; // Master 1250W const int rpmSlave1 = 2500; // Slave VESC different values possible const int powerSlave1 = 1500; // Slave 1500W // Profile 2 values const int rpmMaster2 = 15000; // Master VESC (e.g., 150 km/h) const int powerMaster2 = 25000; const int rpmSlave2 = 15500; // Slave VESC different values possible const int powerSlave2 = 25500; void setup() { pinMode(buttonPin, INPUT_PULLUP); vescSerial.begin(115200, SERIAL_8N1, 16, 17); vesc.setSerialPort(&vescSerial); } void loop() { bool buttonState = digitalRead(buttonPin); if (buttonState == LOW && lastButtonState == HIGH) { profile = !profile; sendVescCommand(profile); } lastButtonState = buttonState; } // Function to send profiles to both VESCs void sendVescCommand(bool profile) { if (profile) { // Control Master VESC vesc.setRPM(rpmMaster1); vesc.setCurrent(powerMaster1 / vesc.getVescValues().v_in); // Control Slave VESC via CAN vesc.setRPM(rpmSlave1, slaveID); vesc.setCurrent(powerSlave1 / vesc.getVescValues().v_in, slaveID); } else { // Control Master VESC vesc.setRPM(rpmMaster2); vesc.setCurrent(powerMaster2 / vesc.getVescValues().v_in); // Control Slave VESC via CAN vesc.setRPM(rpmSlave2, slaveID); vesc.setCurrent(powerSlave2 / vesc.getVescValues().v_in, slaveID); } }

[2025-02-28T14:46:57] francois schempers: Below is an in‚Äêdepth review of your script with several points to note. Overall, the structure is roughly correct for toggling between two profiles and sending commands via a VESC UART interface. However, there are some issues and potential pitfalls: 1. Inconsistent Profile Logic Comment vs. Code: Your comment states: ‚ÄúProfile state (false = Profile 1, true = Profile 2)‚Äù But in your sendVescCommand(bool profile) function the code does: if (profile) { // Sends Profile 1 values vesc.setRPM(rpmMaster1); // ‚Ä¶ } else { // Sends Profile 2 values vesc.setRPM(rpmMaster2); // ‚Ä¶ } This means that when profile is true you are sending what you‚Äôve labeled as Profile 1 values and when profile is false you send Profile 2. You should either update the comments or invert the if/else logic so that they agree. 2. Button Debouncing No Debounce Handling: The code reads the button state with: bool buttonState = digitalRead(buttonPin); if (buttonState == LOW && lastButtonState == HIGH) { profile = !profile; sendVescCommand(profile); } lastButtonState = buttonState; Without any debouncing (hardware or software), mechanical bouncing may cause multiple toggles on a single press. This could lead to erratic profile switching. It is advisable to implement a debounce delay (for example, a delay of 50‚Äì100 ms after a detected press) or use a software debounce routine. 3. Potential Division by Zero Using v_in Without Check: In your commands you calculate current as: vesc.setCurrent(powerMaster1 / vesc.getVescValues().v_in); If, for any reason, vesc.getVescValues().v_in returns zero (for instance, if telemetry hasn‚Äôt been received yet or there is a communication glitch), this division will result in a divide‚Äêby‚Äêzero error. It is best to check that v_in is nonzero before using it or to cache the value once and verify it. 4. Multiple Calls to getVescValues() Inefficient/Non‚ÄêDeterministic Telemetry Calls: In your sendVescCommand function, you call vesc.getVescValues() several times. If these calls fetch data from a volatile source (or if they have side effects), you might get slightly different readings between calls. It is better to store the returned values in a variable and use that variable throughout the function. 5. HardwareSerial and Board-Specific Pins Pin Assignment Issues: You initialize the serial port with: vescSerial.begin(115200, SERIAL_8N1, 16, 17); This assumes that pins 16 and 17 are available for UART on your board. On some boards (especially standard Arduino Uno or similar), pins 16 and 17 may not exist or might conflict with other hardware. Ensure that your target board supports these pins as RX and TX. (On an ESP32, for example, you can often reassign UART pins, but you must be sure your wiring matches your board‚Äôs capabilities.) 6. Assumptions About the VescUart Library CAN Communication Support: Your script uses: vesc.setRPM(rpmSlave1, slaveID); and similarly for setting current with a second parameter for slave ID. This implies that your version of the VescUart library supports sending commands to a VESC via CAN by providing an ID. Not all forks of VescUart have that feature, so make sure your library version does. No Error Checking on Communication: The code assumes that calls like vesc.getVescValues() will always return valid data. In practice, you might want to check for communication errors or timeouts to ensure that your commands are actually reaching the VESC. 7. Data Types and Scaling Integer Literals for Power Values: You‚Äôve defined power values (e.g., const int powerMaster1 = 1250;). Ensure that these values are in the units you expect (Watts). Dividing by v_in (which is in Volts) to get current is mathematically correct if you want current in Amps (since I = P/V). However, check that the VESC expects a float value for current and that your division does produce a float (for example, at least one of the operands should be a float to avoid integer division).
[2025-02-28T14:46:57] francois schempers: Summary Profile Logic: Fix the inconsistency between the comment and code logic. Debounce the Button: Implement a debounce mechanism. Check v_in: Validate that v_in is not zero before using it in a division. Cache Telemetry: Consider storing the result of vesc.getVescValues() in a local variable rather than calling it multiple times. Board-Specific Setup: Ensure that the chosen UART pins are correct for your hardware. Library Verification: Make sure that your VescUart library version supports the CAN slave commands and returns valid telemetry. Conclusion: The script is a good starting point but may not work robustly as written because of the issues mentioned above. If you address the debounce, profile logic, and potential division by zero, and verify that your hardware setup (pins, library functions) matches your target, it should function more reliably.
[2025-02-28T14:49:16] francois schempers: here is a corrected version from the llm
[2025-02-28T14:49:18] francois schempers: Below is a revised version of your script with improvements and corrections based on the issues identified. This version uses a non‚Äêblocking debounce, caches telemetry values, checks for division by zero, and clarifies the profile logic (in this version, we define ‚ÄúuseProfile1‚Äù as true for Profile 1 and false for Profile 2). #include <HardwareSerial.h> #include "VescUart.h" // UART interface for the VESC HardwareSerial vescSerial(1); VescUart vesc; // Button pin and debounce variables const int buttonPin = 0; bool lastButtonState = HIGH; bool useProfile1 = true; // true = Profile 1, false = Profile 2 unsigned long lastDebounceTime = 0; const unsigned long debounceDelay = 50; // milliseconds // VESC IDs (Master = 0, Slave = 1) const int masterID = 0; const int slaveID = 1; // Profile 1 values (e.g., for low-speed mode) const int rpmMaster1 = 2000; // Master VESC target RPM (e.g., ~22 km/h) const int powerMaster1 = 1250; // Master target power in Watts const int rpmSlave1 = 2500; // Slave VESC target RPM const int powerSlave1 = 1500; // Slave target power in Watts // Profile 2 values (e.g., for high-speed mode) const int rpmMaster2 = 15000; // Master VESC target RPM (e.g., ~150 km/h) const int powerMaster2 = 25000; // Master target power in Watts const int rpmSlave2 = 15500; // Slave VESC target RPM const int powerSlave2 = 25500; // Slave target power in Watts void setup() { // Initialize the button pin with an internal pull-up resistor. pinMode(buttonPin, INPUT_PULLUP); // Begin UART communication on UART1 with baud rate 115200 on pins 16 (RX) and 17 (TX). // (Ensure these pins are available on your board.) vescSerial.begin(115200, SERIAL_8N1, 16, 17); vesc.setSerialPort(&vescSerial); } void loop() { // Read the current state of the button. bool currentButtonState = digitalRead(buttonPin); // If the button state has changed, reset the debounce timer. if (currentButtonState != lastButtonState) { lastDebounceTime = millis(); } // If the button state is stable beyond the debounce delay... if ((millis() - lastDebounceTime) > debounceDelay) { // If the button is pressed (active LOW) and was previously released... if (currentButtonState == LOW && lastButtonState == HIGH) { // Toggle the profile state. useProfile1 = !useProfile1; sendVescCommand(useProfile1); } } // Save the current button state for next iteration. lastButtonState = currentButtonState; } // Function to send commands to both VESCs based on the selected profile. void sendVescCommand(bool useProfile1) { // Cache the battery voltage (v_in) from the VESC telemetry. float v_in = vesc.getVescValues().v_in; // Avoid division by zero; if v_in is too low, skip sending commands. if (v_in < 1.0) { return; } if (useProfile1) { // Profile 1: Low-speed mode vesc.setRPM(rpmMaster1); // Calculate current from power (I = Power / Voltage) vesc.setCurrent((float)powerMaster1 / v_in); // Send commands to the slave VESC via CAN using its ID. vesc.setRPM(rpmSlave1, slaveID); vesc.setCurrent((float)powerSlave1 / v_in, slaveID); } else { // Profile 2: High-speed mode vesc.setRPM(rpmMaster2); vesc.setCurrent((float)powerMaster2 / v_in); vesc.setRPM(rpmSlave2, slaveID); vesc.setCurrent((float)powerSlave2 / v_in, slaveID); } } Explanation of Improvements 1. Debounce Implementation: Instead of a simple delay in the loop, the code now uses a non-blocking debounce using millis(). The debounce delay is set to 50 ms. This prevents false toggles due to button bounce. 2. Profile Logic Clarification: The boolean variable useProfile1 now clearly indicates that true selects Profile 1 and false selects Profile 2. The sendVescCommand() function uses this flag accordingly. (Adjust the values if you want the reverse mapping.) 3. Telemetry Caching and Division Check:
[2025-02-28T14:49:18] francois schempers: The function caches the battery voltage (v_in) from vesc.getVescValues() and checks that it is not near zero. This prevents division by zero when computing the current command. 4. Floating-Point Division: The division for calculating current uses a float cast to ensure proper floating-point arithmetic rather than integer division. 5. Code Comments: Additional comments have been added throughout the code to clarify each section and the purpose of variables and functions. 6. UART Initialization Note: The code now reminds you to verify that the chosen UART pins (16 and 17) are available on your target board. --- This improved script should work more reliably and is better documented. Please test it in your environment and let me know if further adjustments are needed.

[2025-03-02T14:56:40] francois schempers: How to Reduce the Delay: 1. Reduce Throttle Ramp Time: - Lower the throttle ramp time (or increase the ramp step) so that the duty cycle increases faster. - Example: If your current ramp time is set to 0.3‚Äì0.5 seconds per step, try reducing it to around 0.1‚Äì0.2 seconds. - *Note:* This change should be done gradually to avoid sudden current spikes. 2. Increase the Startup Boost: - Adjust cc_startup_boost_duty upward so that the ESC gives an immediate higher current at zero throttle. - For instance, if the default is 0.01 (1%), try increasing it to 0.04‚Äì0.06. - *Caution:* Too high a boost can cause abrupt, jerky launches or overstress the components.
